table.task: Learn how to navigate the checklist interface
table.info: Use the side panel to jump between checkpoints and track your progress

table.task: Practice changing task status from Ready to Active to Done
table.info: Click the status button to cycle through states

table.task: Add notes to a task using the notes field
table.info: Use notes to document your approach or findings

table.task: Try clicking the Info button to see helpful examples
table.info: Info buttons provide context and examples for each task

table.task: Reset a task using the Reset button
table.info: The reset button appears when a task is Active or Done

checkpoint-2.caption: Working with Tasks - Managing Your Checklist

table.task: Add a custom task using the Add Row button
table.info: Each checkpoint allows you to add your own custom tasks

table.task: Save your progress using the Save button
table.info: Generate a unique session key to save and restore your work

table.task: View reports to see your overall progress
table.info: Reports show completed tasks and provide an export option

table.task: Delete a custom task you added
table.info: Custom tasks can be removed using the delete button

table.task: Print or export your checklist
table.info: Use the browser print function to create a PDF

table.task: Add alternative text to images with content or function
table.info: Screen readers rely on alt text to describe images to users

table.task: Use sufficient color contrast for text and backgrounds
table.info: Minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for normal text, 3:1 for large text

table.task: Ensure all interactive elements are keyboard accessible
table.info: Users should be able to navigate without a mouse

table.task: Provide clear, descriptive labels for form inputs
table.info: Labels help users understand what information is required

table.task: Structure content with proper heading hierarchy
table.info: Use H1, H2, H3 in logical order without skipping levels

table.task: Never rely on color alone to convey information
table.info: Use text labels, patterns, or icons in addition to color

table.task: Use readable fonts and adequate font sizes
table.info: Minimum 16px for body text, simple sans-serif fonts work best

table.task: Ensure sufficient spacing between interactive elements
table.info: Target size should be at least 44x44 pixels

table.task: Avoid content that flashes more than 3 times per second
table.info: Flashing content can trigger seizures in some users

table.task: Provide visible focus indicators for all interactive elements
table.info: Users need to see where keyboard focus is located

table.task: Provide captions for video content
table.info: Captions benefit deaf users and those in sound-sensitive environments

table.task: Include transcripts for audio content
table.info: Transcripts provide an alternative to audio-only content

table.task: Use plain language and simple sentence structure
table.info: Clear language benefits all users, especially those with cognitive disabilities

table.task: Define acronyms and abbreviations on first use
table.info: Don't assume users know specialized terminology

table.task: Ensure text can be resized up to 200% without loss of functionality
table.info: Users with low vision may need larger text

table.task: Provide multiple ways to navigate content
table.info: Search, table of contents, and site map are helpful navigation aids

table.task: Include skip links to bypass repetitive content
table.info: Allow keyboard users to jump to main content quickly

table.task: Use descriptive link text instead of 'click here'
table.info: Link text should make sense out of context

table.task: Ensure consistent navigation across pages
table.info: Predictable navigation helps users learn and remember site structure

table.task: Provide clear error messages and suggestions
table.info: Help users understand and fix errors in form submissions

table.task: Associate labels with form inputs using proper markup
table.info: Use label elements with for attributes or aria-label

table.task: Group related form elements using fieldsets
table.info: Fieldsets help users understand relationships between inputs

table.task: Identify required fields clearly
table.info: Use both visual indicators and aria-required attribute

table.task: Provide input format instructions before the field
table.info: Tell users what format is expected before they enter data

table.task: Allow users to review and correct information before submission
table.info: Provide confirmation pages for critical actions

table.task: Use table headers to identify columns and rows
table.info: Screen readers use th elements to provide context for table cells

table.task: Provide a caption or summary for complex tables
table.info: Help users understand the purpose and structure of the table

table.task: Avoid using tables for layout purposes
table.info: Tables should only be used for tabular data

table.task: Ensure tables are responsive and usable on mobile devices
table.info: Consider alternative presentations for small screens

table.task: Use scope attributes for complex table relationships
table.info: Scope helps screen readers understand header relationships

table.task: Use semantic HTML elements instead of generic divs and spans
table.info: Elements like nav, main, article provide meaning to assistive technologies

table.task: Add ARIA landmarks to define page regions
table.info: Landmarks like role='navigation' help users navigate efficiently

table.task: Use ARIA live regions for dynamic content updates
table.info: Screen readers can announce changes without page refresh

table.task: Implement proper ARIA states and properties
table.info: Use aria-expanded, aria-selected, aria-disabled as appropriate

table.task: Test with actual assistive technologies
table.info: Automated tools can't catch everything - manual testing is essential

table.task: Run automated accessibility testing tools
table.info: Tools like WAVE, axe, or Lighthouse catch common issues

table.task: Test with keyboard navigation only
table.info: Unplug your mouse and try to complete all tasks

table.task: Test with screen readers like NVDA or JAWS
table.info: Experience your content as blind users would

table.task: Review content with users who have disabilities
table.info: Real user feedback is invaluable for accessibility

table.task: Document accessibility conformance level and known issues
table.info: Be transparent about your accessibility efforts and limitations
